S T A T E   O F   N E W   Y O R K

                              2011-2012 Regular Sessions

                                   I N  S E N A T E

                                   January 11, 2011
                                      ___________

       Introduced  by  Sen. SAMPSON -- read twice and ordered printed, and when
         printed to be committed to the Committee on Education

       AN ACT to amend the education law, in relation to requiring metal detec-
         tors and their use in all schools of secondary education in the state

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section  1. The education law is amended by adding a new section 409-l
    2  to read as follows:
    3    S 409-L. METAL DETECTORS REQUIRED; SCHOOLS OF SECONDARY EDUCATION.  1.
    4  EVERY  SCHOOL  OF SECONDARY EDUCATION SHALL BE EQUIPPED WITH ONE OR MORE
    5  ELECTRONIC METAL DETECTORS FOR USE AT THE INTERIOR ENTRANCE OR ENTRANCES
    6  TO THE SCHOOL BUILDING AND WHICH ARE CAPABLE OF DETECTING  THE  PRESENCE
    7  OF METAL WEAPONS ON THOSE PERSONS WHO PASS THROUGH THE DETECTOR.
    8    2.  EVERY  PERSON  WHO ENTERS A SCHOOL OF SECONDARY EDUCATION SHALL BE
    9  REQUIRED TO PASS THROUGH AN ELECTRONIC METAL  DETECTOR  LOCATED  IN  THE
   10  INTERIOR  ENTRANCE  OF  THE  SCHOOL  BUILDING  BEFORE BEING PERMITTED TO
   11  PROCEED ANY FURTHER INTO THE BUILDING. ANY WEAPON FOUND AS A  RESULT  OF
   12  THE  USE  OF SUCH ELECTRONIC METAL DETECTOR SHALL BE CONFISCATED AND THE
   13  PERSON IN POSSESSION OF SUCH WEAPON SHALL BE DETAINED AND DEALT WITH  BY
   14  THE APPROPRIATE AUTHORITIES IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE MANDATE OF THE LAW.
   15    S  2.  This  act  shall  take  effect  on  the first of September next
   16  succeeding the date on which it shall have become a law.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1692

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the education law, in relation to requiring metal detectors and
their use in all schools of secondary education in the state

PURPOSE:
This legislation would require secondary schools in New York to
install and use metal detectors in order to increase staff and pupil
safety.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
The education law is amended by adding a new Section 409-j. This
section would mandate that all schools of secondary education be
equipped with metal detectors at all interior entrances.

Section 409-j(2) provides that all persons who enter the school
building must pass through the detectors. Any weapons found shall be
confiscated and the person in possession of such weapon shall be
detained and dealt with by the proper authorities in accordance with
the mandate of the law.

EXISTING LAW:
Under current law it is not mandatory for schools to be equipped with
metal detectors in New York State.

JUSTIFICATION:
In the past several years, there has been a rash of school-related
shootings in communities all around the country. These shootings have
resulted in numerous deaths, injuries and trauma for students and
staff alike. There were 36 victims at Columbine high school alone. In
March of this year, a 15-year old student allegedly opened fire at
his school killing one student and injuring fifteen others before
being subdued.
This student's friends were reportedly so concerned about his
propensity for violence that they searched his back-pack before
school began.
Unfortunately, he is alleged to have hidden the gun on his person so
his friends did not know it was there. Had metal detectors been
employed at the school, this tragedy could have been averted.

New York is not immune from school violence. Thankfully there have
been no fatalities so far but the potential certainly exists. Indeed,
on April 5, 2001 an 8th grader in the Bronx was caught trying to
smuggle four bottles filled with gasoline into his school. The
gasoline was discovered after the aluminum foil that he used to wrap
the bottles in set off a metal detector. This potentially deadly
situation was resolved without harm thanks to the prudent use of a
metal detector. This legislation should be enacted in order to help
ensure a safe learning environment in our classrooms statewide.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
S.2501 of 2007
02/06/08 REFERRED TO EDUCATION
S.95 of 2009
01/07/09 REFERRED TO EDUCATION
01/06/10 REFERRED TO EDUCATION

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
UNKNOWN AT PRESENT TIME

LOCAL FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
UNKNOWN AT PRESENT TIME

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the first of September next succeeding
the date on which it shall have become law.
